bibl.title: Despatch from R. Dorsey Mohew to Josiah Quiney, November 12, 1893
Despatches from United States Consuls in Boma, 1888-1895
bibl.publisher: National Archives and Records Service General Services Administration

div1.p:
Mr. R. Dorsey Mohew To the Department of State
Subject: Departure from Lusanh Arab. War.
Abstract of Contents Left Lusambo Nov. 13 Commandant Dhanis last fight against the Arabs.

Honorable Josiah Quincy Assistant Secretary of State Washington, D.C.
Sir: News of a grape character reached here yesterday from Commandante, Dhanis, who is at Kassongo with the State Troops engaged with the assistance of several thousand natives, in suppressing the Arab slaves.

It seems these Arabs have bought from a trading house, either on Lake Nyassa or the South Eastern end of Lake Tanganyika many rifles (repeating) and an enormous amount of ammunition (cartridges, powder, etc..). During the middle of October they arrived near Kassongo, mustering it is estimated 10,000 guns. The Commandant attacked their boma,
or

or palisaded fort, but wont mable to dislodge them. Not having enough ammunition he has not been able to repeat the assault. During the attack Pophaui Pontheir (who dusting wished himself during 1889-90-91-92 as Van deen Kuck hovens second M' the ouelle Bomokandi Rivers.) was severely wounded in back lego and Lieut Lange in the foot +28 soldiers killed. Commandant Dhanis has asked for re-enforcements from Stanley Falls. Basako +Lere. I put what force I had with me, at the disposition of the Government and to Mohew morning Nov. 13th leave with a caravan of 575 persons for Nyangawe + Kassongo, and expect to arrive at the lahter place in 20 days, by marching 10 hours a day.
Respectfully R. Dorsey Mohew Commerical Agent
